PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs as the minister responsible for ASIS. Is it the case that ASIS is holding tens of thousands of files on ordinary Australians, as suggested by the Four Corners program last night? Does ASIS have access to personal files held by other government organisations such as Telecom, the Department of Social Security, Medicare and the Australian Taxation Office? Is the Privacy Commissioner aware of the existence of these files, and does he have any role in preventing the inappropriate use of this information?

—My understanding is that ASIS does have some files, as one would expect in an organisation of that nature, even though its brief extends to activities outside the country rather than inside. They are essentially of an administrative nature. The number of them that could be so described I am not sure of; I will need to get further information about that.

PARA.TAB: The arrangements for oversight and ensuring that privacy guarantees and so on are observed here, as elsewhere, are effectively centred in the office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, an office that was, of course, set up following the second Hope royal commission as the primary method of oversight and scrutiny of ASIS administration. I am confident that no privacy invasion issues have arisen as a consequence—

TALK.START.PARA: —On what basis?

—On the advice that I have received when I have asked about this in the past. I have not sought or received further information about that specific issue since last night; I will do so. But, when I have inquired about this in the past—as I have, because the issue has been raised in various ways in the past—I have been satisfied that the files that are maintained are essentially for in-house purposes and that the oversight arrangements that apply in house and the scrutiny arrangements that apply so far as the independent mechanism of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security are concerned are sufficient between them to ensure that no privacy issue of any proper concern in fact arises.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I reiterate that part of my question that sought to find out whether in fact ASIS has access to personal files held by other government departments such as Telecom. I mentioned Telecom in particular but I referred also to the Department of Social Security, Medicare and the Australian Taxation Office. Also, following from the minister's answer, is the minister saying that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security is aware of all the files that are held, that he has had access to them and that he is satisfied that they do not go beyond issues of national security?

—It is my understanding—and I will seek further information on that matter—that there is no right of access of any automatic kind to those files which might exist elsewhere. Whether any access has in fact been sought on any occasion in the past is something about which I will seek an answer. Whether it is possible to give any further information publicly about this or any other matter of an operational nature is, of course, a difficult question, as is always the case when one is talking about a security organisation. But I do not think, from the briefing that I can recall having in the past on this issue, that any question of this kind arises.

PARA.TAB: ASIS is basically not that kind of organisation. Its brief does not extend to domestic matters of this kind. I cannot think of any circumstances where it would be relevant to seek information of the kind that might be held. But I am not in a position to give an absolute answer, so I will not. Could I ask Senator Hill to repeat the last part of his supplementary question?

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator Evans saying to the Senate that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security is aware of all of these files, that he has had access to them and that he is satisfied that they do not go beyond issues of national security?

—That is my understanding. Part of the inspector-general's brief is to protect the interests of Australian citizens. In order to do that he must, of course, have complete access at his own discretion and choosing to anything he wants to. That is my understanding of the way the system works. Again, if I have any further information to offer on that subject, having sought a more detailed briefing on this specific aspect of the question, I will be happy to give that information if it is possible to do so.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. As the minister is no doubt aware, concerns have been raised about the new charging regime for meat inspection services which came into effect on 1 January 1994. My question comes in two parts. First, what action does the government intend to take to address the concerns raised regarding the charging structure? Secondly, what does the government intend to do to ensure that the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service operates in an efficient and cost-effective way?

—I thank Senator Murphy for his question and his courtesy in giving me notice that he would ask this question. This matter is of interest not just to members of the government but also to a number of senators in the opposition and Senator Woodley from the Australian Democrats. I have held a number of meetings over the last few weeks with interested senators on this issue.

PARA.TAB: The introduction of new meat inspection charges in January followed extensive consultation with industry bodies and consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. Notwithstanding this very exhaustive consultative process, there have been a number of concerns raised about the impact of the new charging regime, particularly on smaller operators. I might add that this problem occurred because the original proposal put forward by the government was for a three-tiered system that contained not just an establishment charge and an inspector charge but also a throughput charge that would have actually reflected the situation of the operators with a smaller turnover.

The proposal was changed to the current two-tiered system as a result of representations that were received by that senate committee and by opposition senators. I have considered the concerns that have been raised about the impact on smaller operators and I have decided on certain changes to the previously announced registration charges. In fact, I discussed this matter just today with the shadow minister, John Anderson, prior to making this statement.

As well as the reduction in rates for the 1993-94 financial year, I have determined that the revised six-monthly rate for 1993-94 will be maintained through to 31 December this year. Increases in establishment registration charges as from 1 July 1994, which had been foreshadowed in discussions with industry, will now not take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Thank you, Senator Boswell. This will allow the government a period to the end of calendar year 1994 in which to examine, in consultation with the industry, the whole question of inspection charges. I have asked AQIS to convene an industry charging review committee to consider further AQIS meat inspection costs and the appropriate charging structures and rates necessary to achieve appropriate cost recovery levels. Any new rates agreed will apply from 1 January 1995. There is a procedural matter in relation to the decision to reduce a number of the registration charges. The rules for the making and tabling of regulations require me to table the original regulations, which I will do today.

PARA.TAB: I propose to table the new regulations by 24 March which will give effect to the changes I have outlined. As well, I am addressing the question of AQIS charges. I am also giving great priority to reducing AQIS costs. As the government announced in the 1993-94 budget, there is to be a major process of reform and efficiency improvement in AQIS. This process involves a restructuring of the Canberra office and regional support services. Efficiency measures in AQIS field services are also being developed. It is my intention to pursue these reforms vigorously. I will shortly be making a more detailed announcement on these matters. I table the revised charges.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of that totally equivocal statement, I ask whether the minister stands by his own assurance in this place on 5 October last—that is, just six months ago—that the government would not:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . go down the path of introducing any new taxes. . .

PARA.TAB: We did make perfectly clear, as I said, as the Prime Minister before me said and as others have done, that we certainly were not going to go down the path of a consumption tax, a GST, a VAT or any of those particular nasties that the opposition has been committed to in the past and is now deeply embarrassed about, and that undertaking absolutely holds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order. The question was very clear and specific: whether the government would stick by its promise not to introduce any new taxes.
—That wasn't the government promise. It was the burden of taxes.

—As I was saying before the comment by Senator Cook, the government said it would not introduce any new taxes—Senator Evans said that in this chamber. That is the question which he has to address his mind to, not some other issue regarding our own policy. We are asking about the government's policy.
—There is no point of order.

—What we have said consistently is that we will not be increasing the burden of taxation. That is no doubt what Senator Cook was thinking of a moment ago. —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the minister aware of the WA Sunday Times editorial and comment piece in last Sunday's edition concerning compulsory voting? Given the recent community debate on this topic, has the government reassessed its support for compulsory voting in Australia?

—I thank Senator Chris Evans for the question and for drawing the articles in question to mind. The Sunday Times and some honourable senators here have been running this issue for some time. It is not very hard to understand. The most basic logic or intellect would enable people to see there is some superficial, pseudoliberal-democratic attraction to that simple argument that the right to vote should entail the right not to vote. That could be argued at a first year philosophy tutorial, but someone would say in return that the response of a citizen in a democracy is that people have to consider the consequences of the policy they are advocating.
—Why has every other country got it wrong?

—Senator Alston is wrong about that. He should go back to playing Torquemada and not worry about this. The fact of the matter is simply that the research on who does not vote is overwhelmingly clear, and it has been consistent throughout the world for as long as I can recall there being research. There is nothing recent, because all those people who do the research say it is a settled question. Everybody knows that it is people of lower socioeconomic status who do not vote; less well-educated people, blue-collar workers and the unemployed. People who have less contact with others in their immediate neighbourhood do not vote.

PARA.TAB: I know that some people argue that it is in some way apathetic or less intelligent people who do not vote. I have to say that is a very insulting argument, but I do not attribute that to Senator Minchin, who has not said that. I have to say that I do not agree with his argument, but he has not made that point.

The concern is that these citizens are not voting, not through greater apathy but because these are the people who already feel excluded from the political system. These are the people who feel that the political system does not serve their interests. An agreement to go to voluntary voting would only reinforce that problem. It is reinforced doubly because these are the people who most need the assistance of government. It is inherent in the nature of a democratic political system that it responds to the active electorate. The skew in the political system would go disproportionately towards those who vote and to the interests of those who vote, and the political system would tend to get skewed away from those in greatest need of government policies. Those whom the policies are designed to serve are those least likely to be assisted.

I find that this a profoundly disturbing trend. I would be shocked to think there are people advocating this policy for partisan advantage. I suspect that they would not dream of it; that everybody who advocates it would get partisan advantage from it is undoubtedly a coincidence. Notwithstanding that, the fact is that it is a fundamental question of principle; we should not allow the political system to develop in such a way that it ignores and underestimates the interests of those most in need of government assistance. That tends to disempower further those who are already feeling locked out of the political system. What is worse, there is a tendency to reinforce the power of special interest groups and the zealots. We can be sure that in the United States every member of the National Rifle Association votes, and that is one of the reasons why it has disproportionate power in the American political system.

I think as a question of principle and as a question of serious consideration of the consequences of an action, it is irresponsible for any government and any participant in the political process who operates within a system of compulsory voting to be advocating turning the clock back to a system that advantages the already privileged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It relates to last night's ABC Four Corners program. What independent oversight of ASIS currently exists? What is so unique about ASIS that, unlike ASIO, the CIA and MI6, it is exempt from all parliamentary scrutiny? Finally, does the minister accept that in the interests of accountability, the government should urgently establish a legislative framework to scrutinise ASIS in the same way as ASIO reports to a joint parliamentary committee?

—It needs to be understood in the light of various calls that have been made for judicial inquiries and so on into the various things that were said in the Four Corners program last night and, indeed, in earlier newspaper articles, that there has been a very substantial judicial scrutiny of ASIS already in its recent history, beginning with the first Hope royal commission in 1977. That commission concluded that ASIS should continue as an organisation under the supervision of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It also established some oversight machinery in the form of the permanent heads committee and the security committee of cabinet.

PARA.TAB: The second Hope royal commission that was set in train by the Labor government after coming into office in 1983 also scrutinised very minutely ASIS's operations as a result, in the first instance, of the Sheraton Hotel incident, which provoked and justified that degree of scrutiny. In Mr Justice Hope's report arising out of that second royal commission he addressed but rejected the notion of a parliamentary committee in favour of the proposal to establish an Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security—which I referred to in answer to an earlier question—which institution has in fact been in place since 1986, with a very full and wide-ranging brief to ensure not only that these agencies comply with their guidelines and statutory obligations and responsibilities, but also that they respect human rights.

I can confirm that under that legislation the inspector-general was given totally wide-ranging powers, including delving into any material he wants to within any of the organisations in order not only to redress particular grievances but also to see for himself how human rights standards, including privacy, are being maintained.

The second Hope royal commission also specifically resulted in a clear government determination that ASIS would not hold weapons and not maintain a capability for special operations or special political action. It was not that ASIS ever had conducted those sorts of operations—notwithstanding a fair bit of public speculation and mythology to that effect—but the government did firmly rule them out from 1985 onwards, denying ASIS the means even to maintain such a capability.

As to the scrutiny provisions that operate in other countries, I think there has probably been some degree of misunderstanding about just how wide ranging those congressional and parliamentary oversight arrangements are. In the United Kingdom, for example, we are seeing right now the passage of an intelligence services act. It makes provision for the appointment of a commissioner who is equivalent, in effect, to our inspector-general, as I understand it, and the establishment of a tribunal to deal with the kinds of matters that have long been dealt with by us, for example, with our security appeals tribunal.It also establishes an intelligence and security committee of parliament jointly constituted from the House of Commons and the House of Lords whose oversight extends over the external intelligence agency in the UK, not just the internal one, and which might be thought to have some relevance as a result.

What needs to be understood—and I do not think it is—is that that legislation specifically allows access by the committee to information to be prohibited in those circumstances where the head of the relevant security service involved certifies that the information is sensitive. And sensitive information includes, among other things, that which might lead to the identification of, or provide details of, sources of information or operational methods; information about particular operations which have been, are being or are proposed to be undertaken; or information provided from another government unless that has been specifically cleared. In effect, there is a total capacity in the way the legislation is drawn to inhibit the access by that particular parliamentary committee to particular information or allegations.
If Senator Bourne asks me a supplementary question I will tell her about the situation in the US.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer to the project announced by the Prime Minister in March 1991 on international performance indicators. Would the minister advise what was the objective of this project and whether a report has now been provided? If there now is a report, what were the findings and were any reasons advanced for those findings?

—There is a report arising from this project announced by the Prime Minister in 1991. In fact, there has been a series of reports, but the report out today from a joint study by the Bureau of Industry Economics and the Business Council of Australia is International Performance Indicators: Overview.

PARA.TAB: Broadly put, the reason for the government sponsoring this report is that with the phasing down of tariffs and the introduction of some transitory support schemes for industry, as we open the Australian economy to international competition in the traded goods area, there is a need also to make the non-traded goods area of the economy efficient and competitive. The way to do that is to push forward micro-economic reform, as the government has been vigorously doing, but to audit that against international benchmarks and against world best practice performance to demark the area in which Australian infrastructure and transport and communications industries can lift their game to the world best practice level so that the overall competitiveness of our economy is increased, not just that area affected by tariff changes.

We have pursued a vigorous micro-economic reform agenda. What this report shows in five areas—electricity generation and distribution; rail freight; telecommunications; road freight; and the waterfront—is that, measured against both productivity gains and the list of costs to users, we have been successful in lifting the performance in those areas of the economy where we have pursued micro-economic reform; although in a salutary note the report also says that in many sectors of the economy there is a way to go before we get those sectors up to world best practice.

I was asked in the question whether I could give some indication of that. It has been discovered in this report that for commodities such as coal and wheat the Australian waterfront is performing at near or at world best practice. We are the best in the world, or very close to it, in terms of operating efficiencies. But Australian port authorities and ancillary coal handling charges are over eight times higher than those of our cheapest competitor, meaning that the costs to the users are higher. Australian industrial electricity prices were ranked as fourth cheapest in the OECD in 1990, but were still 40 per cent higher than our cheapest competitor.

The remarks in this report about telecommunications relate to a period before Optus came into competition with Telecom and therefore to an old competitive circumstance. I will not delay the Senate by referring to that. Road freight was found to be operating at close to world best practice in terms of price and reliability. Australian rail freight systems have improved both in labour and capital productivity, especially on the interstate network. State rail charges, however, are nearly twice as high as our most competitive rail system, Australian National, compared to US best practice rates.

The report also provides some interesting comparisons of performances between the states. For instance, on rail freight charges the New South Wales price per net transport kilometre is 50 per cent above the equivalent measure for Australian National. This sort of comparative benchmarking is a useful tool in spotlighting the deficiencies and measuring progress.

The reasons why these outcomes are evident are referred to in the report as a lack of competition in certain state-owned monopolies, the fact that the rate of change in demand is not adequate, or the fact that there is an inadequate use of technology in those particular areas. It is an important report and I commend it to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the minister's answer, will the issues of micro-economic reform, to which he referred, be taken up in this Friday's COAG meeting?

—Yes. The COAG meeting this Friday is, of course, an opportunity to consider the Hilmer report. The Hilmer report and the report that has just now been released, the one I referred to, relate to micro-economic reform changes necessary in the Australian economy and require a national response. The debate about this is concentrated on what the federal government is doing. The difference here is that it requires a national response and, therefore, all levels of government—federal, state and local—to contribute to lifting the level of competitiveness in Australia. Of course, the federal government wants to see the Hilmer report universally adopted by the states. That view is supported by the Business Council of Australia. Its President, Mr Ralph, said so much in a comment he made yesterday. But we want to see that, in cooperation with the states, we find a way of introducing true competition and, therefore, ensuring a more competitive and efficient economy and improving the overall competitiveness of Australia, not just at the federal level but nationally.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. One point in particular was what other grants made by Mrs Kelly under this program were supplemented with additional funds from general revenue? The other point, which he should be able to address now, is that he said in the answer to the question that the Prime Minister had no involvement with this program. —Again, I will have to check on that and get back to Senator Campbell as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. Is the minister aware of the reports about the dangers of royal jelly and the tragic death of a young girl in New South Wales recently? What action is being taken by the federal government to warn consumers of the possible risks of taking royal jelly?

—I thank the honourable senator for her question. Medical research and the Therapeutic Goods Administration have recently identified 11 cases of severe allergic reaction, including the tragic death of an 11-year-old girl in Cooma and four life-threatening episodes, following the ingestion of royal jelly and royal jelly products. All cases occurred in people with a history of asthma or allergic reaction, and included 10 women and one man. Ten of the cases were reported in the Australian Medical Journal in November 1993 and January 1994. They are believed to be the first reported cases in the world linking the ingestion of royal jelly with severe allergic reaction in asthma or allergy sufferers.

PARA.TAB: The TGA has reviewed the clinical evidence and has determined that consumer safety requires the placement of warning labels on royal jelly products, recommending they should not be consumed by asthma and allergy sufferers. As some royal jelly products are classified as food items, the TGA has also coordinated its activities with the National Food Authority which is arranging for similar warnings to be included on such products. The Australian Association of Asthma Foundations, all consumer organisations and relevant industry and professional bodies are being advised of these developments, and their assistance is being sought to give very wide circulation to this information.

Medical research is being done also at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to identify the particular protein or proteins within royal jelly responsible for the allergic reaction. The TGA will continue to monitor the developments, and may have to vary its warning as the information emerges.

It cannot be stressed too seriously that allergic reactions to products like royal jelly can be fatal. Sadly, that has already happened and we think it is very timely that a product warning be placed on any food product or therapeutic product containing royal jelly. The warning for therapeutic products will read, `Warning. This product contains royal jelly and is not recommended for asthma and allergy sufferers as it can cause severe allergic reactions'.

Alternative medicines and foods have a very significant market in this country, and the National Food Authority is concerned that people might be frightened off alternative preparations such as royal jelly, which is a very significant market spinner in that industry. However, I believe that the concerns of the industry are not significant or important enough to outweigh the government's concern that, if the warnings are not placed on products in the light of the evidence to hand, there may be more severe reactions or even fatalities.

This warning particularly alerts people with asthma or a history of allergy that there may be a danger if royal jelly is taken. It also advises people that one does not have to have a history to develop an allergy to some food products. So, while it gives good counsel to asthma and allergy suffers in particular, it is a warning to people in general to note the advice in relation to this product.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the Prime Minister's joint venture piggery in the Hunter Valley, which the Environmental Protection Agency says creates a high risk to the environment because it will pollute the land, water and air—an environmental trifecta. Why should we believe that the government is serious about the environment when the Prime Minister has such a blatant disregard for it when making a buck is at stake?
—Mr President, I could not hear the last part of the question. There was some noise in the chamber. Could Senator Tierney repeat the last part of the question?
—Would you like to repeat the last part of your question, Senator Tierney.

—Certainly. Everyone else heard it but I am happy to repeat it. Why should we believe that this government is really serious about environmental concerns when the Prime Minister has such blatant disregard for the environment when making a buck is at stake?

—I find that an extraordinary question. I am not certain what those opposite would say about what is inherent in that question—that one cannot have piggeries because they pollute. That is absolutely inherent in the question, absolutely what the honourable senator said, and he cannot walk away from it.

PARA.TAB: In terms of polluting the land, the water and the air, as Senator Tierney has claimed, I understand that a report is being prepared on this subject. There has been an extensive environmental inquiry which has gone through the appropriate processes of the New South Wales government because it is within its power to say yea or nay, or to say yes with conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It hasn't said yes yet.

—No, it has not. I do not think the report has come down. Maybe Senator Tierney has knowledge of what the report will say, but I do not. All I can say is that the Prime Minister's piggery, or any other piggery, has to go through the proper environmental processes laid down in state legislation. That is exactly what is occurring.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am glad the minister has made those points because what the EPA has said about this has been widely publicised in the papers. Let me tell the minister what it found. It found continued land degradation affecting the site, the impact of odour affecting the air and salty effluent affecting the water. The minister says that I am against piggeries. We are not against piggeries; we are against piggeries that are inappropriate for that site. Will the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories tell the Prime Minister to move this inappropriate industry out of the beautiful Hunter Valley where it is wrecking the environment?

—I think it is up to the environment authorities in New South Wales to determine exactly what kind of piggery is appropriate, where it would be appropriate, how it would be managed and what safeguards should be applied to it. That process has been gone through at great length and in great detail. I await, as I am sure do those opposite, let alone the Prime Minister, what the environmental authorities in New South Wales might decide. I am sure, as is the case with every other citizen or every other proposer, that the Prime Minister will abide by the law and abide by those decisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to an article in the Weekend Australian of 12 and 13 February titled `The unsettling of Australia'. The article describes the continuing decline in the population, income and morale of rural Australia. Does the minister agree that rural Australia is in serious decline, and does the minister agree with the University of Queensland demographer, Dr Martin Bell, who states:

QUESTION.PARA: The negative impact of out-migration will be exacerbated in the prevailing climate of `economic rationalism' which promotes the closure of private and public services to country towns.
What plans does the government have to reverse these disastrous trends, or does the government intend in the future to feed Australia with imported food?

TALK.START.PARA: —The poor old English language continues to suffer—in this case from the use of the word `out-migration' in the question. There is emerging evidence—and a great deal of this, as I am sure Senator Woodley knows, was delivered at the ABARE Outlook 1994 conference earlier this year—that the downturn in the rural sector in Australia has bottomed, with signs of recovery in both rural land markets and the price of land, and in the economy generally.

PARA.TAB: Since the late 1980s, a group of producers has continued to face difficulties in achieving long-term profitability but, on the other hand, indications are that many potential investors are benefiting from the build-up of property size and value-adding activities. In terms of the population decline, the facts are, as the statistics demonstrate, that we are in no different position in Australia than in any other developed country in the world.

We have one of the most efficient agricultural sectors in the world. We made it very clear at the time, though, that we were not going to solve the problems of western Sydney by compounding problems that exist in the western area of Melbourne. But the secondary issue to that is this: we have been looking at whether it is possible to have either co-location or co-access to Point Wilson for the armaments depot. —If one looks at the Fraser government's record, it ought to be remembered that those opposite spent nothing. We will spend plenty—the largest single increase since Federation. —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Senator Bourne asked me a question about, among other things, parliamentary scrutiny of the CIA. I did not get time to respond to that part of the question then, but I do so now. The situation in the United States is that there are select committees on intelligence in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, together with Senate and House committees on appropriations. The appropriations committees, or the relevant subcommittees, leave detailed work, including on budgetary matters, to the operational committees, so the relationships with those committees are essentially formal in character.

PARA.TAB: There is quite a substantial working relationship with the two operational intelligence committees, and quite a lot of information is given. However, it is important to realise the limitations in the United States on the supply of information from the executive in sensitive matters. There is an agreed provision, for example, whereby, by presidential directive, sensitive operational material can be provided only to an inner group of the relevant congressional committees.

Moreover, there is a further provision which is the result of the continuing stand-off between the congress and the executive in terms of legislation which embodies this or leaves it out, as the case may be, and that is a presidential directive whereby in extreme cases, where determined by the president in consultation with the cabinet committee, the congress is not to be advised, even in a limited fashion, about particular matters. The stand-off is a result of the fact that congress does not want such a provision, the executive has insisted on it, and the indications are that if ever it went to legislation, the legislation would be vetoed if it did not contain such an exceptional provision.

All that points to the reality of very significant inherent limitations, even in a relatively apparently open system like the United States, which confront efforts to have parliamentary oversight of particularly sensitive intelligence operations. I have described the similar provisions which are there on the face of the legislation in the United Kingdom.

It is because of the inherent limitations involved in any such parliamentary scrutiny that successive governments in Australia have taken the view that it is not especially helpful as a contribution to the oversight of ASIS in Australia, and that that oversight would be better exercised through, in particular, the machinery of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, together with the additional oversight that is exercised by the permanent heads committee of the intelligence community, and also the cabinet security committee. I think that gives additional—and hopefully helpful—background to Senator Bourne and anyone else interested in the policy of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Short on this issue. In the last election the fundamental debate was on the issue of taxes. It was very clear from all public polls and opinion polls taken since the election that taxes was regarded as the fundamental issue.

—The government policy on taxes was, as Mr Keating said, not to raise taxes, to keep taxes as they were. PARA.TAB: Today we had an astonishing performance from Senator Evans. We now know that Senator Evans is not talking about a tax increase but that he is calling the tax increase a levy. Later on in question time, as he stumbled around trying to explain to Senator Short why the government was not keeping its promises, Senator Evans said that it was not a tax rise but a financing mechanism.

I believe that Senator Short has drawn attention to a really fundamental issue—that this government lied its way into office and, within months of winning an election on the promise that there would be no tax increases, it increased taxes by some $3 billion. I believe this government has broken its fundamental promise to the Australian people. I believe the Australian people understand that. That is why Mr Keating has no moral authority whatsoever in this country. Senator Evans gets up and tries to lecture people about standards and morals. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support what my colleagues Senator Short and Senator Kemp have said in response to Senator Gareth Evans's answer to Senator Short's question asked earlier today. As my colleagues have said, potential tax increases are really a serious matter for the Australian community. The Australian community has been misled by the government. The really serious issue for the longer term future is that, whilst the Australian economy is now recovering, business investment has not recovered. It is business investment which sets the scene, not for tomorrow but for a few years time when we get into the next dip in the economy.

PARA.TAB: As I have said in this chamber several times, it is a fact that investment in plant and equipment of less than six per cent of GDP is the lowest rate since World War II. Whilst the Treasury figures which came out this week show that the rate has risen marginally for the latest quarter, it is still nowhere near the amount that is required over the next several years to sustain this economy and provide jobs for our children and grandchildren. We have a long way to go.

A jobs levy—a financing mechanism, as Senator Evans calls it—would really be another impediment to investors considering investing in Australia today. In this morning's Australian, the Managing Director of ICI Australia made the point that his industry is ready to spend billions of dollars in setting up and expanding chemical exports, provided that the impediments to those investments are considered by government and removed. One of the points he made was that the government ought to consider giving a five per cent tax rebate to make up for the indirect taxes which businesses pay in this economy. TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether it is ever worthwhile seeking to clarify these matters because members of the opposition never take any notice anyway. Let me just say that such confusion as beats in their breasts and their heads today is a product of not being able or not wanting to draw a distinction between three quite separate situations: firstly, whether a particular revenue measure is a tax at all; secondly, whether it is a new tax; and, thirdly, whether it involves an increase in tax. They are three quite separate questions, and if honourable senators can understand the difference between those three questions they can understand perfectly well what I, the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and everyone else has been saying over the years.
—Thanks for the help, professor.
—As I say, it is almost a complete waste of time drawing these distinctions, but let me begin at the beginning.
—Ha, ha!

—I know that Senator Harradine is totally familiar with these issues. There is a threshold question, as a matter of constitutional law and as a matter of Senate practice, as to whether a particular revenue measure is properly describable as a tax or whether it is properly describable as a fee, a charge or a levy. When a revenue measure is selective in its application—not of general application to the community as a whole but with a particular target group—it is very often appropriate to describe it not as a tax at all but as a levy or in some other way, such as a fee or a charge.

PARA.TAB: So I make no judgement as to whether a jobs levy, if it were to be introduced, would properly be described as a tax. That might be a matter for argument around the place but it is certainly not a matter for assumption on the part of the opposition. That is the first point I was seeking to make, and that is not a matter for jocularity, parody or anything else; it is just a matter for plain, straightforward understanding on the opposition's side, which is a little bit much to ask for, I know, but I do ask for it.

The second question is whether or not one is introducing a new tax and what we may have said on the subject of new taxes. I do not think the Prime Minister was ever explicit in ruling out new taxes as such—`no new taxes'. The Treasurer was on one occasion in August 1992, I think before the budget, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will not be introducing new taxes.

What precisely the context of that particular remark was I am not sure—whether he was saying so in the context of that budget or purporting to offer a promise more generally; one would have to see the context of the remark.

PARA.TAB: Certainly my own remark on 5 October, which has been quoted today, that the government would not be going down the path of introducing new taxes was simply, again, descriptive of the situation as it stood after the last budget. I am not to be taken as having made any general promise or commitment in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —When do your statements have any commitment?

—It is just a matter of understanding what I am saying and not making up what I am saying and not injecting any more content into it than actually existed. That is what I want to say on the subject of new taxes.

PARA.TAB: Of course, in the context of the last election, before the last election there was one new tax that we were very specifically ruling out and we made that absolutely clear, and that was a GST. Senator Short must wish in retrospect that he had made a similar commitment. He might be doing a little bit better now than he was at the time or is now.

The third question—and it is a distinct one again—is not whether one is introducing a new tax but whether one is increasing an existing tax. On this there is a lot of argument backwards and forwards about what was said before the last election in that respect. The point to be made once again in this regard—and we made it on innumerable occasions—is that the Labor government did not rule out before the last election or at any time subsequently the possibility from time to time of there being revenue increases. What we did rule out was any increase in the overall burden of taxation. Right at the very beginning—in the Lateline contribution of the Prime Minister on 19 November—the context of his response to Mr O'Brien on that occasion made that absolutely clear. He did say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what I'm promising is not to put up tax.

But that was immediately after a sentence in which he said that his object and the government's object was to maintain the tax to GDP ratio that we roughly have at the moment. He said that our object was:
. . . to maintain the tax to GDP ratio we roughly have at the moment. In other words, what I'm promising is not to put up tax.

Honourable senators opposite and I know that what he was saying was that there would be no increase in the overall burden—the tax to GDP proportion—and that is exactly what we are delivering on because the burden throughout the 1980s of tax to GDP was of the order of 23 or 24 per cent and in our particular projections—and all these figures have been on the public record before and debated in this place—we are anticipating no more than that, getting up to about 23 1/2 per cent by 1996-97.

PARA.TAB: So there is a difference between new taxes and existing taxes and there is a difference between not increasing a tax and increasing an existing tax; and, understood in the way that I have stated, there is absolutely no inconsistency in anything the government has said, and certainly no deception of the Australian public.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time today the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) used a dorothy dixer from his former colleague in the west, Senator Chris Evans, to defend the ALP's position on compulsory voting. It is incredible how sensitive the ALP has become on this issue. This is the second time since July that the ALP has used the forum of the parliament to defend its position on compulsory voting. It would appear the ALP is well aware that it is starting to lose the argument on this very important issue.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan used the argument about how voluntary voting would disenfranchise the underprivileged, as though the opposition was suggesting that people should be denied the right to vote. He dismissed arguments about voluntary voting as first-year philosophy arguments.

The issue here is one of naked ALP self-interest about compulsory voting. The ALP has a vested interest in retaining compulsory voting because it believes it gets a very significant advantage from the system of forcing people to vote. It is terrified that its own core voters would not vote if they were not forced to the polls; that is what this issue is about.

Senator McMullan tries to dress it up with arguments about disenfranchising people, and saying that this is really not an issue that we should be addressing. This is really all about the fear that is struck into the heart of the ALP about the notion that people might have the right not to vote. It is very interesting that a former adviser to Mr McMullan, one Rod Cameron, hailed as the ALP's greatest asset through the 1980s as their researcher, is probably Australia's most passionate advocate of voluntary voting. He realises the stupidity of forcing people to vote who have absolutely no interest in election outcomes.

The irony on our side is that there are some Liberals who believe that the ALP would be the beneficiary of having voluntary voting. I have arguments with some on my side who say that the ALP would be better at getting out the vote. That only demonstrates that on our side it is a matter of principle. We genuinely believe that the right to vote must entail the right not to vote. The ALP does not have one shred of principle on which to stand on this issue. Its self-interest is utterly naked. Its attitude to underprivileged voters is utterly condescending and contemptuous. The tragedy is that the ALP thinks it has to force its own voters to the polls or it will lose elections.

The ALP never mentions in this debate the fact that the overwhelming number of democracies in the world do not force their voters to vote. We are the only English speaking democracy that does so. We are one of only five countries in the world that I can find that forces voters to vote.

Senator McMullan dismisses the right not to vote as a first-year philosophy argument. I remind him that in 1970 Holland changed from compulsory to voluntary voting for the very reason that for years some of the most eminent people in Holland had considered this issue. They reported to the Dutch parliament that, as a matter of high principle, the right to vote must entail a right not to vote. As a result Holland got rid of compulsory voting, leaving Australia now as one of the very few countries to retain this very undemocratic system.

The ALP also fails to mention that, in the overwhelming majority of countries that have voluntary voting, voter turnout is around 80 per cent—eight out of 10 voters choose to exercise their right to vote and turn out to vote. The United States of America is often cited by Labor activists as an example of what happens under voluntary voting. But it is the great exception to the rule: for a whole variety of reasons that are inherent to the US it has a low voter turnout. Voluntary voting in the United States tells us that there are real problems with the American political system, and that is why people are not turning out to vote. American political commentators know their system is sick because of that low turnout.

The ALP also fails to acknowledge that almost every analysis of the United Kingdom and United States experience with voluntary voting shows that, for every election studied since World War II, there would have been no change in election outcomes if the polls had been conducted by compulsory voting. It simply would not have changed the outcome of national elections held in those countries since the war. A further irony is that under voluntary voting in America the Democrats, the soul brothers of the Labor Party, have an iron grip on the house of representatives, and have had such a hold for 40 years. So voluntary voting is hardly disenfranchising the core vote of the Democrats in that country and what would be the core vote of the Labor Party in this country. It is tragic that the Labor Party has this perception that it would suffer from giving the people the right not to vote.

The problem in Australia is that, frankly, until now there has been a cosy conspiracy between the parties about compulsory voting. It has been easier for the major parties to have the law force people to exercise their franchise. In other words, the responsibility is taken away from the parties to persuade people of the virtues of exercising their right to vote. That means that we have an electoral system where the total focus is on a handful of swinging voters in a handful of swinging seats. Due to compulsory voting the great majority of voters in this country have almost nothing to do with the political process because they can safely be ignored by the major parties.

The major parties should have the responsibility of persuading voters of the virtues of voting, and if they do not then they will pay the price. It would rejuvenate the sick position of the voluntary organisations of our political parties in Australia—organisations that are in a poor state. This would give organisations a real purpose, a necessity to get out into otherwise safe seats and persuade voters of the need to vote. Compulsory voting is wrong in principle and wrong in practice. It is about time the ALP faced up to the need to give voters the right not to vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to deal with the government's intended review of the link between population growth and development. SPEECH.PARA: . . . we proposed that an appropriate development economist—someone with an international reputation who is fully independent and has no axe to grind on these matters in issue—be asked to spend a few months reviewing the available evidence as to the nature of the relationship between the variables I have mentioned and reporting to the government on that issue.

Actually, I had raised this matter and questioned AIDAB representatives on these issues over a period of time in estimates committees. The Senate will recall that on 7 October 1993, I told the Senate that, if the government were serious about its deficit reduction strategy, it was inappropriate for a minister to commit this sort of expenditure on controversial policies for more than a short period and certainly not for a four-year period, well beyond the term of this parliament.

Although it was claimed by some sections of the media that the person chosen for the review would have to meet my approval, this was never and is certainly not the case. I invite honourable senators to read what he said and see whether the new structure and most of the participants meet that criteria. If there was to be a change of structure, if there was to be a review conducted by a number of people, why were not scholars with well-argued differing viewpoints invited to contribute? Yet here we have $320,000 of aid money being spent by the government on this particular inquiry which does not meet the criteria nor the structure as originally announced by the government.
