SPEECH.PARA: The argument of the population controllers and their political supporters has been that rapid population growth is a crucial negative factor in the economic development of developing countries.
For a number of years now, both inside and outside the Parliament, I have publicly challenged those assertions.

When the 1993/94 budget was announced it contained a three-fold increase in finance for population programs for 93/94 over the previous year and a five-fold increase over four years. This is at a time when the ratio of Official Development Assistance to Gross National Product is, except for one year, at an all time low. This will result in the transfer of funds from poverty alleviation and development co-operation to international population bureaucracies and population control programs.
This increased spending on population control was introduced at a time when the Government had embarked on a deficit reduction strategy which included increases in indirect taxes.

On October 7, 1993, I told the Senate that if the Government were serious about a deficit reduction strategy it was inappropriate for a Minister to commit this sort of expenditure on controversial policies for more than a short period—and certainly not for a four year period, well beyond the term of this Parliament.

The suggestion to test the assumptions upon which the Minister proposed such an increase was made by the Government. The Government decided that a review be undertaken of the literature relating to population growth and development to be conducted by an internationally recognised development economist who did not have a public position to defend, or in the words of Foreign Minister Senator Evans, no axe to grind.
I initially welcomed an objective analysis of the intellectual underpinning for policy in this area, having urged it at Senate Estimates Committee meetings.

Neither the structure of the "inquiry" as now constituted, nor most of its participants meet the criteria proposed by the Government itself and expressed to the Senate by Senator Evans on 27 October 1993, as follows :

". . . we proposed that an appropriate development economist—someone with an international reputation who is fully independent and has no axe to grind on these matters in issue—be asked to spend a few months reviewing the available evidence as to the nature of the relationship between the variables I have mentioned and reporting to the government on that issue."

The "appropriate development economist" whom Senator Evans envisaged would spend a few months reviewing the available evidence has turned into nine people—each one to contribute a chapter in a book. This was not the original intention as stated in the Senate on October 27. With the change in structure why were not scholars with well argued differing viewpoints invited to contribute?

The Minister for Development and Pacific Island Affairs, the Hon Gordon Bilney, has appointed as team leader, Professor Dennis Ahlburg of the University of Minnesota, a long-time consultant with the World Bank who has expressed views in support of population programs of a type proposed for the Pacific by AIDAB.

Professor Ahlburg has contracted eight people to assist with the review, most of whom have publicly stated positions in support of population programs. Although the Government stated the consultant to be involved in the review was to have "no axe to grind" the positions of most of the appointees are ones which require defence.

In a letter from Minister Bilney's office dated February 15, I was told that "the Government was careful to select independent specialists who are internationally well regarded to undertake the inquiry." Yet the Minister had already told me he had not heard of many of the appointees.

My office is currently in the process of a search of the written views of the appointees. A large number of articles have been received and more are coming. It is also receiving information from international contacts as to the otherwise expressed views of the appointees.

Those whom Ahlburg has appointed to provide the chapters on housing and health have published positions which require defence. In that sense they have an axe to grind or an intellectual sand castle to defend, and should not have been appointed. The Minister was not aware of their published positions prior to their appointments; I have had searches done and although the appointees were little known, what was known shows that they support population programs of the type proposed by AIDAB.

There is no credible development economist who would now say that population growth is a necessary crucial negative factor in economic development. As to food, agricultural scientists and the World Bank point out that agriculture prices are at their lowest level in history and that world food production is rising faster than population. Hunger does exist among plenty; people are living in extreme poverty.
The argument that population has to be controlled to achieve economic development has always been dubious.
There has been one basic theme to the argument:
By reducing population growth countries can increase savings for investment and thus achieve a sustained take off to higher economic growth rates.
This has led to corollaries such as
Countries should not subsidise families through family allowance programs since these have the effect of increasing the rate of population growth;
Countries should use so-called non-coercive incentives such as cash payments, priority for housing and schooling etc for parents with fewer children.

Taking the fundamental argument first, at its most simplistic it seems to assume that output is fixed and that by reducing the numbers of the population, we can produce a greater output per head. This is obvious nonsense.

First, it ignores the greater efficiencies in production which can arise through specialisation which becomes possible in serving larger markets. How often, for example, do we hear that the Australian market is too small for our companies and that they must expand overseas to keep up with best world practice?

Second, even if it were true that simply cutting numbers increased output per head, who should the population planners cut? The young or the aged or the mentally and physically disabled? From their pseudo-rational utilitarian viewpoint, the planners might find a greater so-called economic return by culling those who are longer productive rather than potential workers and taxpayers.

Sometimes the argument is a little more sophisticated. For example, Andrew Mason, one of the persons chosen for this review, has advanced the argument that a demographic transition from a high fertility high mortality population to a low mortality low fertility population creates an opportunity for economic growth. Because families pass through a phase where there are few elderly dependants and few child dependants and the past baby boom is of working age, a developing country may be able to increase its savings and investment. This is supposed to lead to a permanently increased rate of economic growth.

Thus in his co-authored study on Population Growth and Economic Development: Lessons from Selected Asian Countries at pp 54-55 the statements are made that "Efforts to reduce fertility have immediately reduced the number of child dependants without reducing the number of adults of working age. The result has been a rapid increase in per capita income for three reasons: (1) fewer children has meant fewer mouths to feed; (2) fewer children has enabled more women to enter the labour force; and (3) fewer children has led to lower aggregate consumption, higher saving, and additional investment in physical capital. . . . . As the [demographic] transition is completed, labour force growth slows and savings rates return to lower levels, the rate of economic growth should return to rates not substantially different from those observed prior to the transition . . . family planning efforts apparently have been successful in bringing down birth rates. This externally induced decline in fertility has had an important bearing on . . . the size and productivity of their labour force, the level of saving, and the growth of per capita and total product. Thus the evidence presented here indicates that the rapid pace of economic growth is, in part, a consequence of successful family planning efforts."

However, the sorts of economic models used by writers such as Andrew Mason suffer from the same problems as the sorts of models used by the Treasury and the Reserve Bank in giving Australia the greatest recession since World War II. These models do not project far enough into the future.

Just as there can be a favourable demographic pattern for a time, so it can change to an unfavourable one. Japan, Germany, most of Europe, the USA and Australia are experiencing the economic strains of ageing populations. With unfunded social security spending and a declining base of taxpaying younger workers, the treasuries of most advanced countries are facing a perpetual battle for solvency.

As tax rates are increased to make up the revenue, fewer taxpayers can afford to raise children and more emigrate or simply evade taxes. History may not repeat itself, but depopulation seems to be creating a situation of flux in Europe not seen since the days of the later Roman Empire.

In a very real sense, the measured economic growth from having fewer children and more investment is a statistical illusion. The concept of gross domestic product by definition excludes human capital. The birth of a pig is seen as a positive, the birth of a child is not. But if we consider human capital as a resource similar to physical capital the concept of GDP changes completely.

For example economists have suggested that investment in human capital in the USA dwarfs investment in physical capital. If we are to believe most economic writers, human capital is crucial to economic growth and competitiveness. If it were not we would hardly be spending so much on education and training.

But you cannot have investment in human capital without parents investing their time and energy in rearing children. When we take human capital into account we see that the so-called economic growth is a shift from investing in people to, at best, investing in plant and equipment. But the apparent increase in physical capital may not even be enough. The growth in incomes per head may even be frittered away in higher consumption, as many of today's workers expect someone else's children to pay the taxes to support them in old age.

If anyone doubts the primacy of human capital over physical capital in development, look at Japan and Germany from 1945 to 1960. The physical destruction of the greatest war in history was overcome well within a generation. As John Stuart Mill observed the knowledge and skills of the people of a country are more important than its stock of capital.

Another statistical illusion used in promoting the benefits of population control programs is the suggestion that GDP is increased by increased female labour force participation when they have fewer children.

The first error in this assertion is to ignore the disutility of labour—a woman may be happier not being in the paid labour force and enjoying her children. Second, the shift of work out of the home into the factory does not necessarily mean increased economic welfare. A poor woman in the developing world who works in a factory and pays for baby formula instead of breastfeeding is increasing GDP per head but her family's welfare may be reduced rather than increased.

The problem with Professor Mason and his colleagues is in the assumptions of their models. It is bad enough when economic modellers inflict recession on us: but playing with demography may be a terminal disease for nations.

A corollary of the view that population growth needs to be reduced to improve economic growth is the suggestion, made by Dr. Cynthia Lloyd, another of the appointees (in her article An Economic Analysis of the Impact of Government on Fertility: Some Examples from the Developed Countries in vol 22 of Public Policy (1974) pp 489-512) that "any government of a developing country seeking to introduce programs designed to reduce population growth would do well to consider all available means of increasing the direct and/or indirect cost of children as currently perceived by couples in the reproductive age group." (at p 507).

Dr. Lloyd suggests that "in all developed countries of the world, costs of children would be even higher than they now are were it not for extensive subsidies to children in the form of family allowances . . . ." She even describes tax allowances for dependants as child subsidies.

Unfortunately, the facts seem to have got overlooked. The Australian Bureau of Statistics in its fiscal incidence analysis has shown that most families pay their own way—by and large two parent couples with children receive no net subsidy from the Treasury. She is also wrong in describing child tax allowances as a subsidy—they are no more a subsidy than the tax free threshold.

So talk of non-coercive inducements to parents by way of fiscal penalties or bribes is wide of the mark. It is coercive to tax people without regard to dependants and then offer them a so-called subsidy paid for out of their own money.

Sometimes advocacy of family planning occurs without any real analysis in support of the proposal. For example, Professor Mark Montgomery, another of the appointees, in a chapter on "Accommodating Urban Growth in Sub-Saharan Africa" in a World Bank Symposium on Population Growth and Reproduction in Sub-Saharan Africa urges the need for "concerted efforts toward family planning" to lower urban growth. Yet, unlike the rest of the chapter, which analyses economic arguments for correcting distortions in the financing of urban infrastructure and labour market imperfections, no real evidence or analysis is offered in support of the a priori policy conclusion in favour of birth control. He does not explain why or how couple's fertility decisions are distorted or why governments have superior knowledge to decide optimum fertility decisions for their peoples.

Sometimes those who advocate population control programs seem to think they know better than the people themselves about what they need. For example Professor Ian Diamond, the appointee to contribute the chapter on family planning, has stated that in Botswana "ideal family size remains high. . . . the mean ideal family size for all women was 4.7 children; for those in a union the ideal was 5.4. It should be an early goal of the population policy to reduce this figure if a sustained fertility decline is to occur. . . . " (Naomi Rutenberg and Ian Diamond Fertility in Botswana: The Recent Decline and Future Prospects Demography vol 30 No 2 May 1993 p 155).

Not only does it seem somewhat out of place for an Englishmen in this post-colonial era to be musing about an apparent need to persuade black Africans to stop breeding, but one wonders how these poor black people are to be reprogrammed. What if they don't want to change? It is a short step from this sort of sentiment to coercive target driven population control programs and the abuses of human rights they necessarily entail.

One of the most serious flaws with the review is the failure to have a person of international stature examining the human rights implications of population programs. From a survey of written work, it seems Karen Oppenheim-Mason, who will be contributing the "human rights" chapter for the review, has not had a prominent role in subjecting coercive population control programs to scrutiny. She is involved in a project relating to "Women and Development" funded by the Rockefeller Foundation—an institution with a long history of support for population programs.
The Australian Government acknowledges the rights of couples to choose freely the number of children they have. It has stated it will not support coercive programs.

R.E Stenshold, Assistant Director General Appraisal, Evaluation and Sectoral Studies Branch, AIDAB has stated: "It is Australian policy that aid is directed only to international organisations that fully respect the rights and beliefs of the peoples they serve."
Because the violation of human rights inherent in many population programs is a pressing issue requiring serious attention, a person of international repute should have been appointed.
The central point of this inquiry is supposed to be a review of relevant literature on the question of population and development.
Will this "review of the literature" include the work of women, particularly those in developing countries, who have condemned population programs as racist, eugenic, anti-women and anti-poor?

Will "Reproductive Rights and Wrongs: The global Politics of Population Control and Contraceptive Choice" by Betsy Hartmann be read and noted? Hartmann states in that book: "the complexities of the argument and the wide variation in opinion have largely been screened from public view."
I hope the "complexities of the argument" and the "wide variation in opinion" will not be screened by the academic appointees.
And what about other literature documenting the violation of human rights inherent in target-driven population programs funded by the Australian taxpayer?

What of the book: "Imperialism and the Control of Women's Fertility: New hormonal contraceptives, Population control and the World Health Organisation" by the Amsterdam-based Indian women's health activist Sumati Nair.

In it, Nair documents the development and trials of new long-acting provider controlled contraceptives and the Anti-HcG vaccine. Does the Senate know that International Planned Parenthood Federation and the World Health Organisation have approved and recommended Norplant for general "contraceptive" use in family planning programs while admitting that not enough is known about the long-term effects of this contraceptive?
She writes of "the misery and suffering" caused by contraceptive testing, and the inundation of unsafe hormonal contraceptives in a context of an inadequate health care system.

The book condemns the World Health Organisation's Special Program for Research Development and Research Training in Human Reproduction (HRP). She writes that WHO is merely promoting the interests of the population control lobby.

And what about the written work against the anti-HCG vaccine—which works not by preventing conception, but by making a woman's immune system produce antibodies to attack the embryo. Will this critical material merit attention for the review panel? Will the panel note that this vaccine is currently being trialled on women in third world countries in the absence of informed consent? Who's helping fund the trials of this vaccine? Australia. And who helped develop it in the first place in collaboration with the WHO? Australia's very own professor Warren Jones. And why does Professor Jones think this vaccine is such a great achievement? I quote from an article in the West Australian May 31, 1990: "He said it would be vital in controlling the world's swelling population.." and in an AAP article: "On Current Statistics, overpopulation threatens to be the real misery of the world—it makes the AIDS problem look like a tea party."
Perhaps Third World women's activists are right to feel that the new provider controlled contraceptives and abortifacients are not designed to empower them or raise their status, but to control them.

There are other books I could mention. "Norplant: Under her Skin" produced by the Women and Pharmaceutical Project in the Netherlands documenting field studies by women's groups in Indonesia, Finland, Brazil, Thailand and Egypt; "A Question of Control" by Health Action International; and the many publications put out by the development policy organisation UBINIG in Bangladesh opposing population control programs.

Then there's the banned book which I have referred to in this chamber before. "The Right to Reproduce: A History of Coercive Sterilization" by Stephen Trombley. The review team should take a look at that one, but they'll be lucky to find a copy. It's no longer on sale thanks to threatened libel action the International Planned Parenthood. The IPPF didn't like references to funding by large US corporations, nor did it take kindly to a critical light being shed on it's anti-fertility activities in the Third World. So much for freedom of speech.

Then of course is the work of the China expert Dr. John S. Aird who has collected a remarkable amount of documentation from sources within China on the workings of the coercive one-child policy. Those of you who were concerned enough would have read the document John Aird produced for this chamber titled:"Foreign Assistance to Coercive Family Planning in China" which I tabled in May 1992.

And if the team is at all concerned with upholding human rights, then it must read the latest book by Steven Mosher "A Mother's Ordeal." Anyone attempting to maintain the myth that China's population control program is not coercive; anyone who thinks that forced abortions up to the ninth month of pregnancy; forced sterilisations, fines, punishments, and discrimination against "illegal" children are not a daily fact of life for the people of China, needs to read this book.

In appointing the nine academics to conduct the review, the Government seemed to forget this country's "Buy Australian" campaign. A total of $320,000 of Australian aid money is being spent on academics (sight unseen) in American universities and population centres. Not one cent is provided to development economists in Australian institutions.

Given the background and the expressed views of the participants, I hope I am not being unduly cynical in suspecting that the outcome of this review will be that there is no proof that population growth is a necessary crucial negative factor in economic development, population growth is substantially the cause of environmental degradation, ill health, low housing etc and therefore more money from international organisations and world governments should be provided to meet an unmet demand for contraception.
Will the so called "right to contraception" eclipse the basic human right to form and found a family and the rights of couples to determine family size without the interference of the State?
Will it eclipse the right of women to exercise free and informed consent before having dangerous long-acting contraceptive and abortifacient drugs injected into them?
Will the review team put forward real alternative policies to the mass dumping of contraceptives on the developing world?

Will it tackle the real reasons for maternal mortality, such as respiratory diseases, parasitic infections, genital mutilation, shocking hospital conditions, anaemia, malnourishment and lack of vaccination, transport and diagnosis facilities for difficult births—often first births.
The Ehrlich theories have been proven wrong.

The world has not run out of food. The real cost of food has fallen and most countries are seeing a surplus of labour arising in agriculture. Indeed, as we know in Australia, commodity prices for agricultural produce have tended to be depressed by glut than driven up by scarcity.

Nor has the evidence shown that population growth is a crucial negative for economic development. On the contrary, there are plenty of examples of territories with both rapid population growth proceeding in tandem with rapid economic growth. For example, Hong Kong, has coped with a huge expansion of its population since World War II while raising living standards dramatically. Malaysia has experienced strong economic growth at the same time as its population is advancing. Few economists would now assert that rapid population growth as such is a negative for economic development.

The population controllers continue to pile up more reasons to justify their interventions. Not only is the fertility of poor women in poor countries now to blame for slow economic growth, it is also responsible for other problems, particularly environmental degradation, poor health and poor housing.
If the fertility of poor women from poor countries continues to be blamed for these situations, target driven programs will continue to be funded.

But here again they fail to look deeper at the root causes of these problems—economic mis-management by governments, war, corruption, the absence of a stable rule of law and political maladministration. Nor should we overlook the simple reality of greed and man's inhumanity to man. It is easier for governments, in particular, to blame their populations than to admit their failures, just as it easier for Australian governments to blame the world economy for our problems instead of looking to what they can and should be doing. But we should not be sidetracked by excuses. The present economic position of the Philippines owes more to the late President Marcos' administration than to its people.
The poet Milton saw reality more clearly when he wrote:
"Accuse not Nature, she hath done her part;
do thou but thine, and be not diffident
Of wisdom, she deserts thee not, if thou
Dismiss not her, when thou most needest her nigh"

When it comes, for example, to environmental degradation, rather than treating human beings as some sort of vermin not fit to roam the earth, we should look at the reasons behind pressure on resources. Often, it will be seen that bad land tenure and land taxation systems are a major cause of problems. When peasants from North East Brazil are driven off the large estates and denied land to live on, of course they will head towards the Amazon rain forest or into the favelas of Rio de Janeiro.

Similarly, with poor housing it will often be found that high land prices caused by tax-induced speculative pressures have meant people do not have enough to spend on the structures they wish to live in. In other cases, there is simply no security of tenure at all and people have no legal right to build anything.

There is not space here to examine all the causes of every social or economic problem, but any careful observer, before blaming population growth as the cause of any problem, will undertake a real examination of more proximate and immediate causes of the particular problem being investigated.

Another new propaganda line says that there is an "unmet demand for contraception"; that access to these "modern" methods is a basic right; and that governments should contribute substantially to population control programs to meet this unmet demand.
Developing world women have a lot of other unmet needs but these have fallen by the wayside because of the overemphasis on contraception.

Finally, a more cynical line is starting to emerge to justify population control programs. Perhaps the review team will also cite alleged "self interest" as a reason for funding population control. The U.S., which recently increased population control spending, admitted this as a reason for doing so.

J. Brian Atwood, director of the Agency for International Development, said population is directly linked to political stability. "There's a very serious problem that is on the horizon here with respect to food security. We are now seeing the levelling of food production in the world as the population increases. This is contributing to instability."

The review team has a serious task before it. I hope that my concerns will be allayed and its publication will examine the relative costs and benefits of population programs in achieving improvements in development indicators vis a vis alternative policies.

—Time ran out earlier this afternoon for motions to take note of answers to questions. I wish to speak on the compulsory voting issue. I support Senator Minchin's statement on the adjournment in relation to compulsory voting. I thought it would be useful for those who study this issue to have listed in Hansard the countries that do have compulsory voting. It is difficult to obtain that material, and I have had an interest in this for some years.

PARA.TAB: Australia is the only English-speaking nation in the world that has compulsory voting. There eight other countries that have compulsory voting. They are Argentina, Belgium, Brazil, Greece, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Zaire and Italy. But recently Italy had a referendum, and I understand that part of that referendum was the question of whether or not to go back to voluntary voting. But at present it still does have compulsory voting.

As Senator Minchin noted, the Netherlands discontinued compulsory voting in 1971. It is interesting to go through the history of compulsory voting in this country. A private member's bill was introduced into the Australian parliament on 16 July 1924. It was supported by all parties at that time and passed on 31 July 1924. It has not been reviewed since.

In finalising that list I should mention there are three separate areas which have partial compulsory voting. Austria has compulsory voting for its president in three of the states. In France the Senate has compulsory voting, as do some cantons of Switzerland. But they are the only countries in the world that have any interest in compulsory voting. Yet it is dredged up here in Australia as being some article of faith as part of democracy, when surely democracy and, in turn, liberty, should be extended to the freedom not to vote.

There seems to be in the Labor Party some peculiar view that research has shown that it favours the non-socialist parties. Interestingly, analysis shows that it really does not matter much whether there is compulsory voting or non-compulsory voting. Purely on the aspect of freedom of choice, surely there is an argument to have the right not to vote. I welcome a debate on this, but neither time nor place is convenient at the moment. I look forward to such a development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin and Senator Herron are totally wrong. There is nothing in the Commonwealth Electoral Act that refers to compulsory voting. What it refers to is compulsory attendance at the polling booth. Neither they nor I will know whether anyone voted in an election, nor should we ever know. That choice is up to the elector. The elector may make the choice in the privacy of the polling booth whether to fill out the ballot paper.

PARA.TAB: There is no law in this land that can compel anyone to vote. Those opposite are wrong. The matter was considered in discussions of the electoral committee when I was on it in the early days in 1983-84 when we considered a whole raft of electoral reforms. Let me note for the record that some interest by the coalition parties has been shown in electoral reform, because from 1949 to 1983 they did nothing in the electoral area other than to malapportion electorates.

Even when this was cleaned up in 1974-75, the National Party blackmailed the Liberal Party because that party did not agree to introduce the 5,000 square kilometre provision into the Electoral Act. Those opposite did nothing about closing hours or reforming postal votes. They did nothing about electoral funding or proper redistributions. They atrophied and did nothing about electoral reform for about 40 years. Now there is a sudden interest in this. I do not know whether it is in their self-interest or whether compulsory attendance at booths rather than compulsory voting should be done away with. But this great libertine thing they are pressing always has a great element of hypocrisy because their party would not extend the same right to electors, the right not to have a compulsion on them to extend their preferences.

The coalition says it should not be compulsory to vote—there is a more technical way to put it—but if it is, it should be compulsory for preferences to be extended. The coalition has always opposed an optional preferential system. It will not give the voter the choice there. So the coalition wants to give the voters the choice as to whether they go to the polling booth, but once they are there the coalition wants to compel them. If it is so into freedom and so on, it should give voters the choice. If voters want to extend their preference right out through the candidates, the coalition should allow them to do so; but it does not.

We have a relatively fair system of electoral laws in this country, but self-interest has always intervened on the way through. One of the classic cases is that of changing governments in New South Wales. Every time there was a Labor government we got rid of postal votes—because they did not help us. Every time the coalition won, that was the end of absentee voting; and so on. But we do have a relatively fair electoral system in this country, standing up and measured against any other electoral system in the world. It is all a matter of checks and balances, and some compromises. So there will never be the perfect system; there is no perfect system for any country.

When coalition senators say they oppose compulsory voting, they are really saying they oppose compulsory attendance at a polling booth. We will never know whether a person voted, nor should we. I hope that if they are going to pursue this as an issue, intellectually they will try to grasp whether they should continue to advocate compulsion of extension of preferences, or whether they should extend that freedom as well.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 16 November 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the precise state of negotiations between the Commonwealth and the States in regard to the integration of the hospitals.
(2) What are the issues which are causing difficulties in each case.
(3) Who is conducting the negotiations in each case.
(4) What is the preferred timetable for resolving the situation in each case
(5) What guarantees have been made, and what form have these guarantees taken, in regard to the treatment of veterans in Western Australia.
(6) What guarantees will be put in place to ensure that veterans are given priority in those states where privatisation occurs.
(7) In the case of each State, what consultations have taken place with the veteran community regarding the future of the repatriation hospital in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Repatriation General Hospital (RGH) Hollywood has been sold to Ramsay Health Care Pty Ltd with settlement to be completed on 24 February 1994. MacLeod Repatriation Hospital was closed on 22 January 1993 and RH Kenmore is expected to be closed by 1 July 1994. The Queensland Government is expected to make a decision on whether the State will integrate RGH Greenslopes in February 1994. Negotiations in respect of RGH Daw Park and Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital are being undertaken at the Ministerial level. The Department of Veterans' Affairs and NSW Health officials are developing a position paper in respect of Lady Davidson Hospital Turramurra.
(2) The States need to be sure that the hospitals have a long term community role and financial and industrial matters need to be satisfactory for both the Commonwealth and the State.
(3) The Minister for Veterans' Affairs assisted by the Deputy President of the Repatriation Commission.
(4) February to March 1994.
(5) and (6) Entitled veterans and war widows will have the benefit of the Repatriation Private Patient Treatment Principles which will come into effect on 24 February 1994.

The Treatment Principles require the Repatriation Commission to provide timely treatment for veterans and war widows. In Western Australia veterans will be treated under contractual arrangements agreed with Ramsay Health Care Pty Ltd and as Repatriation private patients within the WA hospital system.
(7) A National Monitoring Committee was created and a Monitoring Committee in each of the States has been established as follows:
NSW Treatment Monitoring Committee—5 November 1991
Victorian Treatment Monitoring Committee—18 November 1992
Queensland Treatment Monitoring Committee—12 October 1993
South Australian Treatment Monitoring Committee—29 June 1992
Western Australian Treatment Monitoring Committee—12 November 1993
Northern Territory Treatment Monitoring Committee—20 February 1992
ACT Treatment Monitoring Committee—29 April 1991
Tasmanian Treatment Monitoring Committee—1 November 1991
Prior to the establishment of these Committees, there has been extensive consultation with ex-service organisations in each State.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 12 January 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) To what extent has the Minister considered the report entitled A study of the old-growth forests of East Gippsland (Draft, July 1993, Woodgate, Peel, Ritman, et al, DCNR Victoria) in allowing, refusing, or attaching conditions to export woodchip licences.
(2) Does the Minister accept the above report as satisfying the spirit of the National Forest Policy; if not, why not.
(3) In particular, does the above report satisfy the second criterion of the precautionary principle, as set out on page 49 of the National Forest Policy.
(4) Has the Minister written to the Victorian Government concerning the East Gippsland forests and, in particular concerning the above report and/or the East Gippsland Forest Management Plan (DCNR).
(5) Will the Minister release with the answers to these questions any letters referred to in (4); if not, why not.
(6) Are there any agreed criteria between the Commonwealth and the States as to whether fauna are an integral component of any old-growth forest.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Responsibility for the renewal of woodchip export licences and the attachment of conditions to them, lies with the Minister for Resources, the Hon David Beddall MP. As Minister for the Environment, I have only an advisory role in determining the conditions attached to woodchip export licences. The advice I provided to the Minister for Resources, prior to his decision to issue export licences, reaffirmed the need for Commonwealth decision-making to adequately incorporate its legislative and policy obligations concerning the environment.

The Australian Heritage Commission (AHC) is currently in the process of identifying National Estate areas in the East Gippsland region through a joint project with the Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR). Data developed in the study of old-growth forests of Gippsland have been used in this process to assist in identifying National Estate places. Advice regarding this region was provided to the Minister for Resources by the AHC for his consideration in determining licence renewals and conditions.

(2) The Government is still awaiting the release of the final report of the East Gippsland old-growth study to evaluate. However, the study is expected to satisfy that part of the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS) which calls for assessment of forests for old-growth values. As the first study of its kind, the Government expects that methodologies developed in this study will be of value in undertaking future old-growth assessments elsewhere.

(3) The methodology of the old-growth study is based on a series of assumptions with regard to data. These assumptions are based on expert scientific opinions and include a level of precaution. It should be remembered that the report from the study identifies old-growth forest in the region. It is not a management prescription and does not discuss management options to which the precautionary principle could be applied. These issues will be more appropriately addressed in the Forest Management Plan currently being developed by DCNR.

(4) I have written to the Victorian Government regarding forest and conservation matters, however there has been no correspondence specifically concerning the East Gippsland old-growth forest study or the yet-to-be-developed East Gippsland Forest Management Plan.
(5) There are no letters.

(6) The definition of old-growth forest agreed to by governments in the NFPS focuses on forest in which the upper stratum or overstorey is in the late mature to overmature growth phases. Old-growth itself is a structural condition of flora and the agreed definition of old-growth forest necessarily focuses on the floral components of the ecosystem. The importance of old-growth forest to the protection of many species of fauna is well understood.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment,

QUESTION.PARA: Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 24 January 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the National Forest Policy Statement moratorium clause protect forests of high conservation value other than old growth and wilderness forests.
(2) How much forest, other than old growth and wilderness, is of high conservation value.
(3) What types of forest, other than old growth and wilderness, have high conservation value.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The NFPS clause in question only applies to activities that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.

(2) Signatory governments to the NFPS have agreed to review the appropriateness of the existing reserve system. As part of this review, all forest communities will be assessed against reserve selection criteria and areas of high conservation value identified for protection. Only when the results of the review are at hand will it be possible to say how much forest, other than old growth and wilderness, is of high conservation value.
(3) The review referred to above will identify the types of forest, other than old growth and wilderness, that are of high conservation value.
